data.title: What Is A ZIP+4 Code & Why Does It Matter In Data Management
data.meta_description: Address postal codes have been used since the 20th century when postal services in various countries began experimenting with different ways to sort and deliver mail more efficiently. data.text:
Ah! Never thought these could be two different things right?

The fact is, they are often used interchangeably, but there are subtle differences that is important to know if you’re in data management.

Here are some key differences:

ZIP Code Postal Code Country Used in the United States Used in countries around the world Length Always 5 digits Varies in length and format (e.g. 6-8 characters in UK) Structure Numeric only, may have 4-digit extension (ZIP+4) Alphanumeric, may include letters and/or numbers Purpose Used for mail delivery and sorting within the United States Used for mail delivery and sorting globally

While the basic function of ZIP codes and postal codes is similar – to help sort and deliver mail – there are some differences in their structure and use. ZIP codes are specific to the United States, while postal codes are used in countries around the world. Additionally, ZIP codes are always five digits in length, while postal codes can vary in length and format.

Zip codes are important in data quality management because they provide a way to geographically identify and segment data, as well as help with improved marketing campaigns, customer profiling, and demographic research.

Here’s an example scenario to illustrate why zip codes matter in data quality management:

Let’s say you work for a retail company that wants to target its marketing efforts to customers in specific regions. You are responsible for creating a database of customer information, which includes names, addresses, and purchase history.

To ensure the accuracy of your database, you need to validate and standardize the zip codes for each customer. This is important because zip codes can vary in format and spelling, which can cause errors and inconsistencies in your data.

For instance, a customer might provide an address with a misspelled or incorrect zip code, such as “12345” instead of “123456”. Without proper validation and standardization, this data would be useless for targeted marketing purposes.

By using zip codes to segment your data, you can gain insights into customer behavior and preferences in specific regions. For example, you might find that customers in one zip code tend to buy more high-end products, while customers in another zip code prefer budget-friendly options.

In the event that you have poor quality ZIP code data and you do not clean, match, or standardize it before business use, your company may risk:

Failure to validate and verify the data against government databases

Marketing and other business operation failures

Misdeliveries, delayed shipments, unhappy customers

Failure to meet compliance requirements

ZIP codes and postal codes are extremely important identifiers of a database. In the UK for example, postal codes are used across government bodies to identify the location of an individual. If this data is not accurately matched with the individual’s identity, it may result in real-world challenges such as inaccurate credit reports, identity theft, and so on.

It is therefore necessary for ZIP codes to meet data quality benchmarks before it is used for business purposes.

Some organizations may underestimate the importance of ZIP codes in especially if they are not directly involved in the ecommerce, mail, or shipping industry.

However, ZIP codes can be used for:

Geo-located targeted marketing: ZIP codes allow businesses to segment their customers by location, which enables targeted marketing campaigns based on geographic demographics, local events, and purchasing behaviors.

Fraud prevention: In some cases, ZIP codes can be used as an additional security measure to prevent fraudulent transactions. For example, requiring a ZIP code for credit card transactions can help verify that the person making the purchase is the rightful cardholder.

Customer segmentation: ZIP codes and postal codes can also be used for customer segmentation. By analyzing the distribution of customers across different ZIP codes and postal codes, you can identify patterns and trends that can help you tailor your marketing efforts and product offerings to different segments.

Regulatory compliance: In some industries, the use of ZIP codes and postal codes is required for regulatory compliance. For example, in the insurance industry, ZIP codes are often used to determine premiums and coverage areas. Ensuring that your data is accurate and up-to-date with the latest ZIP codes and postal codes can help you stay compliant with these regulations.

Data quality management: ZIP codes and postal codes can be used as a part of data cleansing efforts to ensure that your data is accurate and up-to-date. By comparing your data to a reference database of ZIP codes and postal codes, you can identify and correct any errors or inconsistencies.

How you make use of ZIP codes depends on what you want from your data. But for ZIP codes to truly be effective, it’s necessary that they are validated and verified by matching against the USPS database before they can be used.

ZIP + 4 code data is often raw data that needs to be profiled, cleansed, and matched against the USPS database to ensure its accuracy and validity. Performing these steps manually takes ages and is often inaccurate. Because it’s such a mundane, high-risk, and mind-boggling task, most organizations tend to simply ignore it and rely on unstructured or semi-structured address data.
